member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.AppSettingsConfigurationProvider
member.summary: This provides an implementation that utilizes the out of box capabilities of the .NET app.config file's <appSettings> element.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProvider
member.summary: This interface defines the methods to acquire configuration values. It allows a developer to supply their own custom configuration provider.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProvider.Initialize(System.String)
member.summary: This method should be called by any application as part of a two phase constructruction of a new instance prior to invoking any GetValue() calls. This allows derived classes to implement and to perform any required initialization.
member.param: A string value, the format of which is defined by the derived class, to allow a custom provider to acquire any specific values needed. The format of this value is completely up to the provider for which it is used. For example, the AppSettingsProvider makes no use of this at all and the RxpConfigurationManagerProvider passes in a comma delimited list of values representing the ComponentName and Environment to which to connect.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProvider.GetValue``1(System.String)
member.summary: This method is called to acquire a configuration value. Implementors override this method to provide custom implementation. The base class implementation handles passing the call down the chain when a derived class chooses to not process.
member.typeparam: The type of value being retrieved. The expected types are instrinsic types like int, string, DateTime, etc.
member.param: The name of the configuration value to retrieve.
member.returns: Returns the value of the requested configuration item.
member.remarks: Implementors of derived classes should implement this method such that when it cannot locate the value to return it calls the base class implementation which will pass the call down the chain or throw a exception if there are no more providers in the chain.
member.exception: Thrown when the requested configuration value does not exist.
Thrown when the requested configuration value does exist but cannot be represented by the data type specified by the type parameter.
Thrown when the application has removed all registered ConfigurationProvider instances from the chain.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProvider.GetValue``1(System.String,``0)
member.summary: This method is called to acquire a configuration value or return a specified default if not found. Implementors override this method to provide custom implementation. The base class implementation handles passing the call down the chain when a derived class chooses to not process.
member.typeparam: The type of value being retrieved. The expected types instrinsic types like int, string, DateTime, etc.
member.param: The name of the configuration value to retrieve.
A default value to be returned if the requested value is not found by the active configuration manager.
member.returns: Returns the value of the requested configuration item.
member.remarks: Implementors of derived classes should implement this method such that when it cannot locate the value to return it calls the base class implementation which will pass the call down the chain or return the passed in default value if there are no more providers in the chain.
member.exception: Thrown when the requested configuration value does not exist.
Thrown when the requested configuration value does exist but cannot be represented by the data type specified by the type parameter.
Thrown when the application has removed all registered ConfigurationProvider instances from the chain.

member.summary: A class that encapsulates the management of pluggable configuration value providers.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.Initialize(Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProvider)
member.summary: This method has been deprecated. Replace the existing call to Intialize() with Chain() or Replace(). Use Chain() if you want to use the NextConfigurationProvider property to handle all unhandled configuration values, use Replace() to mimic the deprecated Intialize() method most closely.
member.param: n/a

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.Chain(Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProvider)
member.summary: Inserts the new at the front of the chain of existing s. This allows custom providers an ability to override for a subset of values and invoked the default handler for those values not specifically handled.
member.param: The user supplied object instance to use in the library for obtaining configuration values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.Replace(Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProvider)
member.summary: Completely replaces the existing chain of s with the supplied in the parameter. Use this only when the default provider serves not purpose and you want to completely control all configuration values with a single provider.
member.param: The user supplied object instance that will be used to replace the existing active provider.
member.returns: Returns a reference to the chain of providers that was replaced.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.Remove
member.summary: Removes the that is at the front of the chain of existing s. This method is essentially the opposite of the Chain() method.
member.returns: Returns a reference to the head node that was removed. The NextConfigurationProvider property of this node will have been set to null in order to completely disassociate it from the the remaining chain.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.Clear
member.summary: Clears all configured providers from the manager's provider chain.

member.summary: Searches the chain for a of the type specified by the parameter and returns the first instance found. If not found null is returned.
member.param: The type of to find and return.
member.returns: The first of the type specified by the parameter or null if not found.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.Current
member.summary: Gets the currently configured object to be used. (The default if not explicitly set is an instance of which reads the current executable's app.config file.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.ExceptionHandler
member.summary: A callback event for which an application can register so that any exceptions that are thrown from a call to acquire a configuration value from anywhere in the chain of handlers are passed to the registered handler allowing it to wrap it in a application specific exception.

member.summary: Internal class used only to wrap calls to the chain of providers so that exceptions that might be thrown can be wrapped and rethrown based on the registered exception handler(s).

member.summary: Creates a new instance initializing the NextConfigurationProvider instance to the passed in value.
member.param: The instance to which all the real work will be delegated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.ConfigurationProviderManager.RootConfigurationProvider.GetValue``1(System.String,``0,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Private method that wraps the call to the next provider in the chain in a try/catch and allows all exceptions to be handled by the registered exception handlers;
member.typeparam: The type of value being retrieved. The expected types instrinsic types like int, string, DateTime, etc.
member.param: The name of the configuration value to retrieve.
A default value to be returned if the requested value is not found by the active configuration manager.
True to make the pass through call NextConfigurationProvider.GetValue<T>(name), false to call NextConfigurationProvider.GetValue<T>(name, defaultIfNotFound).

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Core.CoreGlobals.GetPerformanceCountersInstance(System.Type)
member.summary: Returns instance of the instrumentation performance counters for the type T. As the diagnostics cache manager is a generic class, one separate instance of the performance counters needs to be maintained for each type for each the class is used. This method maintains and returns the instance of InstrumentationPerformanceCounters for the provided type.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.ApplicationEventManager
member.summary: This class provides capabilities to retrieve event definitions from an XML file and deserialize them into a instance to be used for logging purposes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.ApplicationEventManager.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructs an instance of ApplicationEventManager using the section of the that is passed in.
member.param: Name of the <Module> section that contains the events to be created by this instance.
The XML to be used. This is typically an imbedded resource.
member.remarks: The recommended practice is to create a ApplicationEvents.xml file as an imbedded resource for every compiled binary. Each file is capable of defining events for multiple modules.
member.example:
Here is a sample configuration file that can be processed by this class:
<Module Name="MDM.Adapter" > <Events> <Event Name="TestEvent" MonitoringEventId="1234" MonitoringEventType="Error" Category="2"> <Message>This is the message of the event and it support the use of substitution parameters:{0}{1}{2}</Message> <Cause>This element should contain information regarding what caused the event</Cause> <Instructions>This contains instructions for steps to be taken for monitoring and corrective action.</Instructions> </Event> </Events>
<Events> <Event Name="TestEvent2" MonitoringEventId="5678" MonitoringEventType="Information" Category="0"> <Message>ditto</Message> <Cause>ditto</Cause> <Instructions>ditto</Instructions> </Event> </Events> </Module>
member.exception: Thrown when the does not contain a 'Module' element that matches the passed in.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounters.IncrementCounterGroup(System.String,Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.Timer,System.Action)
member.summary: This is a convenience method that will update an arbitrary number of counters based on whether or not the code block throws an exception and how the counter group is defined in the metadata.
member.param: The name of the group of counters that is to be processed.

An optional parameter that, when supplied, will be used to perform the timing of the duration of the callback. Pass this parameter only when your application has implemented the interface and you want to use the same timings value for both the Timer instrumentation and the corresonding PerformanceCounter.

An optional callback for the code that is to be wrapped by this method. When a callback is supplied the wrapper will time the duration of the callback. When the callback passed in is null no timing will be produced and since there can be no such thing as a failure the group counters that have an IncrementCondition of 'Always' or 'Success' will be incremented.
member.returns: The length of time taken to execute the method.
member.remarks:
This method will use the following logic to update/increment performance counters that were declared as part of the passed in as follows...
A timer is started just prior to calling the and stopped immediately upon return. If an 'AverageTimer32' counter is defined in the group it will be updated with the elapsed time.
If the does not throw an exception all PerformanceCounters declared with an IncrementCondition=Success will be updated.
If the does throw an exception all PerformanceCounters declared with an IncrementCondition=Failure will be updated.
Regardless of whether the throws an exception or not all PerformanceCounters declared with an IncrementCondition=Always will be updated.

member.summary: Gets and sets a value that specifies the maximum number of objects to cache in memory before flushing to persistent storage. derived classes should honor this value by flushing data when this value is exceeded or when the application has been idle for the period of time specified by the property. member.name: P:Microsoft.IT.Configuration.CacheManagerOptions.MaxTimeToCache
member.summary: Gets and sets a value that specifies the maximum time any timer can remain in the in-memory cache before flushing to persistent storage. derived classes should honor this value by flushing data when this value is exceeded or when the count of cached timers exceeds the value of the property. This value is initially established via the 'maxTimeToCache' attribute of the 'timerOptions' element in the config file and default is 00:05:00.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingMode
member.summary: Enumeration that defines the various types of Ping method requests. Each value specified represents a different level of diagnostics to be returned from the call to the Ping method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingMode.ConnectivityOnly
member.summary: A value that is requesting the Ping method to simply return the server's machine name, IP address and current UTC DateTime. This value is not passed on to the OBA dispatcher and provides no additional validation or diagnostics.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingMode.FullEndToEndDiagnostics
member.summary: A value that is requesting full diagnostics be performed and every infrastructure component required in the processing of the request be tested with results of the test(s) being returned as an individual entry in the collection. This value implicitly includes the results from a ConnectivityOnly test.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingRequest
member.summary: Represents the request object that is passed as a parameter to the method and defines the level of diagnostics that are to be performed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingRequest.PingMode
member.summary: Gets and sets a string value that specifies the processing that is to be performed. Use the string constants defined in the static class to populate this property.
member.remarks: Note that custom values can be supplied provided the web services being called have been designed to handle the values passed. The static class defines the standard values that implementors are obligated to support.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResult
member.summary: Enumeration that provides the values to be returned for individual diagnostic test run during the course of a Ping method invocation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResult.None
member.summary: Represents an unspecified value. (Integer value = 0)

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResult.Success
member.summary: The test result was successful. (Integer value = 1)

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResult.Warning
member.summary: Indicates that a problem was detected with some aspect of the infrastructure but if all other functions are reported as functional the services would still be able to handle the request via some sort of built in reliability or failover feature. (Integer value = 2)

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResult.Failure
member.summary: Indicates that that a problem was detected with some aspect of the infrastructure that will prevent the services from functioning. These results should be escalated immediately. (Integer value = 3)

member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResults
member.summary: The response class that returns a collection of object instances that reflect the status of the call.

member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResults.ToString
member.summary: Returns a human readable string that represents the current object.
member.returns: A human readable string that represents the current object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResults.Responses
member.summary: Gets the collection of object instances that reflect the statuses of each specific test performed in the processing of the call to the Ping method.

member.name: P:Microsoft.IT.DataEntities.PingResults.Result
member.summary:
Gets a computed value that returns an aggregated value representing the result status of the overall call to the Ping method. The value returned is a value as follows:
None (0) - if the PingResults collection was empty.
Success (1) - if all the s in the collection were successful.
Warning (2) - if at least one warning is present and there are no errors in the collection.
Error (3) - if there is at least one error in the collection.

member.summary: Enumeration that describes the type of timer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Unspecified
member.summary: Generic timer

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.AppDomainTransition
member.summary: Represents a that is a close approximation of time spent 'on the wire' for calls that cross machine boundaries. This TimerType is always created by the reporting UI by computing the ElapsedMilliseconds as the difference between the sum of the durations of a timer's children and the timer's duration. This is similar to except this value represents time spent on the network accessing a web service.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Application
member.summary: Represents a created by an application. All timers that are not created by the timing infrastructure are of this type.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Behavior
member.summary: Represents a created by an application provided channel stack behavior on either the client or server.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Client
member.summary: Represents a created on the TimerBehavior on the client prior to posting to a WCF service.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Compression
member.summary: Timer created by the Compression encoder on both client and server.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Operation
member.summary: Represents a that is the amount of time spent performing the actions of a WCF operation. This TimerType is set by the TimingBehavior after pulling the application provided timer from the IInstrumented interface implementation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Overhead
member.summary: Represents a that is the amount of time that is not explicitly accounted. This TimerType is always created by the reporting UI by computing the ElapsedMilliseconds as the difference between the sum of the durations of a timer's children and the timer's duration. This is similar to except this does not involve cross app domains.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Placeholder
member.summary: This value is used by the infrastructure only to manage the child timers throughout the WCF channel stack. Certain operations require timer placement in the hierarchy prior to the actual timer having been received from a WCF call. These types of timers are never persisted or reported and always get replaced.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.TimerType.Service
member.summary: Represents a created by the TimerBehavior on the server hosting a WCF service.

member.summary: Used to provide error specific information to the trace listener infrastructure. Use this method whenever an exception is being reported.

member.summary: Logs an event using the data passed in the and parameters. The 's Message, MonitoringEventId and MonitoringEventType are used in the call directly and the Cause, Information and Name are added as extra information to the log text.
member.param: The to be written.
The exception to be included in the log entry.

member.name: M:Microsoft.IT.Diagnostics.NamedTraceSource.LogEvent(System.Exception,System.Object[])
member.summary: Logs an event using the data passed in the parameter. This method will retrieve any existing that exists in the exception's Data collection and use those values for EventId and EventType. If the is of type then this method will extract/remove the and delegate the call to the overload. If none of the above conditions apply the exception.Message property will be the logged message with EventId of zero and EventType of Error.
member.param: The exception to be logged.
A list of objects that are to be converted into human readable dumps of the object data and included in the event.
member.remarks:
Note that this call has the potential for altering the passed in exception by removing any that was previously set. This facilitates the logging of the exception with the low level root cause information then rethrowing a new exception with a new that wraps the root cause exception and describes a different situation.
For example, a library throws a ConfigurationException using an ApplicationEvent describing the error. One application might just log the error then failover to a cached configuration and continue. Another application, however, may need to treat the error as fatal and shutdown. If this app just wrapped the existing ConfigurationException in a FatalException there would be 2 conflicting entries. Instead, the ConfigurationException should be logged first, then the escalated FatalException should wrap the now clean root exception and allow the last exception to be logged.

member.name: T:Microsoft.IT.ServiceModel.TimingBehavior
member.summary: Extends the behavior of a contract to include timings captured at the relevant and interesting points of a method call. This WCF behavior implementation takes care of timing end-to-end the execution time of a service call and provides programmatic access to the timing data so that server hosts can accumulate subordinate timings. It also provides programmatic access to the client to also extend the timing collection and implement a custom reporting method. This class can be used as both an Endpoint behavior (configured via app.config) or a Contract behavior (configured via attributes on the contract).

remarks.para:
This behavior manages the exchange of Timer between the proxy and the behavior via a [ThreadStatic] property. This property is only considered valid in the following 2 cases:
That period of time between an application setting the client proxy Timer property just prior to making a web service call and the point that the BeforeSendRequest event fires;
That period of time between when the AfterReceiveReply fires and the application retrieves the Timer from the client proxy.
This convention works for both synchronous and asynchronous calls because we are always reasonably guaranteed that the application will not spawn new threads to set or retrieve the Timer. This is in fact a similar approach to how .NET manages the OperationContext.

Once the behavior fires at the beginning of the request the timer moved to a collection that tracks internally via the WCF MessageId. This unique identifier is carried through to reply as the RelatesTo property in the WCF header. At the last possible moment the managed Timer for the request is moved to the the ThreadStatic property for the client to be able to access without requiring the need to know a 'key'.

member.name: F:Microsoft.IT.ServiceModel.TimingBehavior.proxyRootTimers

member.summary: Builds the channel factory.
member.param: The BindingContext context.
member.returns: A new IChannelFactory instance.
member.remarks: Whenever a binding is instantiated, WCF creates a ChannelBuildContext which contains the sequence of the binding elements that shall be stacked onto each other into a channel or listener stack and starts stacking them from top to bottom by invoking the topmost binding elements BuildChannelListener or BuildChannelFactory method. Once the binding element is done creating its channel factory or channel listener, it invokes BuildInnerChannel[Listener/Factory] on the context to have the binding element underneath do its work. Our binding element wont create a channel factory or listener, but rather put itself into the BindingParameters collection on the build context and will then just have the context complete the construction work.
